Award.AwardTitle: ICES: Small: Collaborative Research: New Approaches to Computationally Protecting Elections from Manipulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Election mechanisms are broadly used in computational settings, including a rapidly expanding range of applications in multiagent systems. Twenty years ago, responding to results showing that all reasonable elections systems can be manipulated, Bartholdi, Orlin, Tovey, and Trick proposed protecting election systems from manipulation by making the attacker's task computationally prohibitive, e.g., NP-hard. Their work started a rich line of research, yielding many such computational protection results.

However, a number of weaknesses in this approach have emerged: (1) Much of the work assumes that voters have complete, transitive preferences and that the manipulator has perfect knowledge of the preferences of each voter. (2) Many election systems have polynomial-time algorithms for perfect manipulation and so cannot be computationally protected. (3) Even when there are NP-hardness results, these assume all ensembles of voters are possible, and it has recently been shown that when one looks at, for example, voters obeying the common behavior model known as single-peakedness, these NP-hardness results often evaporate. (4) Even when there are NP-hardness results, they are worst-case results, and so it is possible that often-correct heuristic attacks exist.

This project will respond to these weaknesses, rebuilding the computational approach to protecting elections and more rigorously delineating its limitations. More natural and realistic models will have strong consequences in terms of the weaknesses discussed above. Complexity theory and algorithmics will both be developed in a broad investigation of the above weaknesses and techniques to go beyond them to retain the value of using complexity theory to protect election systems against manipulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is in the area known as computational social choice theory.

The goal of this project was to develop new ways to computationally protect elections from manipulative attacks, especially in light of the intense recent push to circumvent protections. Arguably the most powerful line undercutting computational protections of elections is the broad range of work showing that for electorates that are "single-peaked" (the most important model of electorate behavior in political science), the existing intractability results no longer apply, and indeed, in many single-peaked settings it is known that polynomial-time algorithms exist to compute optimal attacks.  A quite different line undercutting the computational protection of elections is to argue that typical-case algorithms may exist that very often do well even on intractable problems.

The work of this project developed responses to these argument lines.  For example, it indeed is true that many intractability results evaporate when the electorate is single-peaked. But under the current grant we intensely probed that line for its limitations. Though this is a quite strong research line, its Achilles' heel is the fact that in the real world electorates are not *perfectly* in line with single-peakedness: there will essentially always be some mavericks who go outside the boundaries of the so-called single-peaked axis. So we have studied whether the bypassings-though-single-peakedness of hardness results remain valid for *nearly* single-peaked electorates.  Prof. Edith Hemaspaandra, my former student (now himself a young professor) Piotr Faliszewski, and I have obtained a range of results, and the answer varies by setting, but we have shown that as few as one maverick can jump the complexity from P right back up to intractability, i.e., can fully restore the lost complexity-theoretic protection; in other settings where that does not hold, the number of mavericks for which the p-time algorithms are valid often is either just a constant or logarithmic number.

This project supported my student Curtis Menton's Ph.D., and Curtis now works for Google in Mountain View, CA.  In addition to many research results, this project also resulted in two surveys that appear as chapters in the new Springer textbook "Economics and Computation: An Introduction to Algorithmic Game Theory, Computational Social Choice, and Fair Division," which is the first textbook on computational social choice, and in the Handbook of Computational Social Choice, which will be published in January 2016 by Cambridge University Press.
